greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Pascal's triangle - 1.
comment: T(n,k) = A109128(n,k) - A007318(n,k), 0 <= k <= n. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Apr 10 2012
Indexed as a square array A(n,k): If X is an (n+k)-set and Y a fixed k-subset of X then A(n,k) is equal to the number of n-subsets of X intersecting Y. - _Peter Luschny_, Apr 20 2012
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Rows n=0..100 of triangle, flattened
formula: T(n, k) = T(n-1, k-1) + T(n-1, k) + 1, 0 < k < n with T(n, 0) = T(n, n) = 0. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jul 18 2015
If seen as a square array read by antidiagonals the generating function of row n is: G(n) = (x - 1)^(-n - 1) + (-1)^(n + 1)/(x*(x - 1)). - _Peter Luschny_, Feb 13 2019
example: Seen as a square array read by antidiagonals:
maple: with(combstruct): for n from 0 to 11 do seq(-1+count(Combination(n), size=m), m = 0 .. n) od; # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Apr 09 2008
# The rows of the square array:
Arow := proc(n, len) local gf, ser;
ser := series(gf, x, len+2): seq((-1)^(n+1)*coeff(ser, x, j), j=0..len) end:
for n from 0 to 9 do lprint([n], Arow(n, 12)) od; # _Peter Luschny_, Feb 13 2019
xref: Triangle without zeros: A014430. Row sums are in A000295.
Diagonals of the square array A(n, n+d): A030662 (d=0), A010763 (d=1), A322938 (d=2).
results.author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
